Options.Value: Optimistic
Supplicatory
Sympathetic
Piteous

Question 1.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

‘Careened,

These oily tears

Dripping down the tears on your depressed face

Will one day be staunched,

I swear!’

Ibiwari Ikiriko, Oily Tears.

The tone of the poet is
Question 1.Explanation: An optimistic tone retains the belief of expectance of the best or at least a favorable outcome. In the lines, the persona hopes that the tears and suffering of the person addressed will soon cease.

Options.Value: Quatrain
Couplet
Free verse
Limerick

Question 2.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

‘Lift not the painted veil which those who live call life:

Though unreal shapes be pictured there,

And it but mimic all mimic all we would believe

With colours idly spread,-behind, lurk fear.’

P.B.Shelley, Sonnet

The stanza above is an example of a
Question 2.Explanation: A quatrain is poem of four lines or a stanza of four lines.

Options.Value: Personification
Praise
Symbolism
Apostrophe

Question 3.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

‘Symbol of fruitfulness, symbol of barrenness

Mother and destroyer, the calm and the storm!

Life and desire and dreams and death

Are born of the sea; this swarming land.’

Frank Collymore, Hymn to the sea.

The address to the sea in the lines above is done by the use of
Question 3.Explanation: An apostrophe is a figure of speech in which an inanimate object is addressed like a human or an absent person is addressed as though present. Here, the sea is addressed like a living creature.

Options.Value: Rejection
Anger
Protest
Nausea

Question 4.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

‘When he gave me the bottle, and I opened it, I was shocked by the odour that hit my nose. I immediately corked it again, and spat on the floor.’

Isidore Okpewho, The Last Duty.

The reaction in the passage above is that of
Question 4.Explanation: The persona immediately feels unwell and has a strong urge to vomit after the perceived the content of the bottle. This is a feeling of nausea.

Options.Value: Humor and irony
Allusion and paradox
Irony and parody
Hyperbole and allusion

Question 5.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

CYCLIST gets down and begins to prop his bicycle

CYCLIST: All right. If you’re sure it won’t take long

BARBER: I am known for my lightning clippers. Even the soldiers know me. I can shave the head of an entire battalion between one coup and the next. Sit down and relax your back. Cycling is not easy when you’ve abandoned it for some time….’

Wole Soyinka,The Beatification of Area Boy.

The literary devices in the dialogue above are
Question 5.Explanation: The statement made by the barber is an obvious exaggeration. This is an example of hyperbole. Also, he made mention of a coup; an example of historical allusion.

Options.Value: The days of Noah
Rain and flood in June
Discomfort and likely destruction
An animal, insects and fun.

Question 6.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

A storm half out to sea kept turning around like a dog trying to settle himself on a rug;

We were the fleas that complained in his hair.’

John Updike, wash

The images set in the lines above are of
Question 6.Explanation: The mental image formed in the mind of the readers of the poem is that of the rain and storm causing a lot of damage as the sea overflows its bank.

Options.Value: Delivery
Musicality
Repetition
Oratory

Question 7.Question:
This question is based on Literary Appreciation.

‘We have been asleep, Mr. Speaker, my fellow citizens; asleep in our dream of security! Asleep in our well-meaning, sportsmanlike way of wishing the other fellow well. Asleep in the false security of accepting all men goodwill who would be free as men of honour.’

Ralph Ellison, Juneteenth.

The force of the speech above is sustained on
Question 7.Explanation: Repetition is the engaging and recurring use of a particular word or phrase in order to create an effect. In the lines, the word ‘asleep’ is repeated to create emphasis on the person’s message.

Hostile
Theoretical
Eloquent

From the passage above, Thomas Gradgrind is
Question 8.Explanation: The poem portrays the unbending nature of Thomas Gradgring whon believes in only his knowledge and will not accept any other person’s opinions.

Question 9.Explanation: The master is in a state of awareness, concentration and focus which filters experience and information. For example, a state of meditation or possession by some being.
